#!/bin/bash

echo "Setting up SDDM (Simple Desktop Display Manager)..."

# Install SDDM
echo "Installing SDDM..."

sudo pacman -S --noconfirm sddm qt6-5compat qt6-declarative qt6-svg

echo "Enabling SDDM to start at boot..."
sudo systemctl enable sddm.service --now

sudo cp ~/dotfiles/Extras/Extras/usr/share/sddm/themes/simple-sddm/ /usr/share/sddm/themes

sudo cp etc/sddm.conf /etc/sddm.conf

cd ~/dotfiles/

# Show confirmation message
dialog --msgbox "SDDM has been installed and enabled to start at boot." 10 50

clear

#!/bin/bash

echo "Setting up SDDM (Simple Desktop Display Manager)..."

# Ask user to install SDDM
install_sddm=$(dialog --title "Install SDDM" \
  --yesno "Do you want to install SDDM (Simple Desktop Display Manager)?" 10 50)

# Check user's choice
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
  echo "Installing SDDM..."
  sudo pacman -S --noconfirm sddm

  # Ask user if they want to enable SDDM at boot
  enable_sddm=$(dialog --title "Enable SDDM" \
    --yesno "Do you want to enable SDDM to start at boot?" 10 50)

  # Enable SDDM if user wants
  if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "Enabling SDDM to start at boot..."
    sudo systemctl enable sddm.service --now
    dialog --msgbox "SDDM has been installed and enabled to start at boot." 10 50
  else
    dialog --msgbox "SDDM has been installed but not enabled to start at boot." 10 50
  fi
else
  dialog --msgbox "SDDM installation canceled. Exiting." 10 50
  exit 1
fi

clear

#!/bin/bash

echo "Setting up SDDM (Simple Desktop Display Manager)..."

# Install SDDM
echo "Installing SDDM..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm sddm

# Enable SDDM to start at boot
echo "Enabling SDDM to start at boot..."

# Show confirmation message
dialog --msgbox "SDDM has been installed and enabled to start at boot." 10 50

clear

echo "Installing main packages and application that I personally use the most..." && sleep 1

# Function to display the browser selection menu
install_browser() {
  # Display the checkbox menu
  choices=$(whiptail --title "Browser Selection" \
    --checklist "Select the browsers you want to install:" 15 50 6 \
    "   Zen-Browser   " "" OFF \
    "     Firefox     " "" OFF \
    "    Chromium     " "" OFF \
    "     Vivaldi     " "" OFF \
    "   qutebrowser   " "" OFF \
    "     Brave       " "" OFF \
    3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)

  # Check if the user pressed Cancel
  if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
    echo "No selection made. Exiting."
    exit 1
  fi

  # Process the selected options
  for choice in $choices; do
    case $choice in
    "\"   Zen-Browser   \"")
      echo "Installing Zen-Browser..."
      paru -S --noconfirm --needed zen-broswer-bin
      # Video Download Helper
      curl -sSLf https://github.com/aclap-dev/vdhcoapp/releases/latest/download/install.sh | bash
      ;;
    "\"     Firefox     \"")
      echo "Installing Firefox..."
      sudo pacman -S --noconfirm firefox
      ;;
    "\"    Chromium     \"")
      echo "Installing Chromium..."
      sudo pacman -S --noconfirm chromium
      ;;
    "\"     Vivaldi     \"")
      echo "Installing Vivaldi..."
      paru -S --noconfirm vivaldi
      ;;
    "\"   qutebrowser   \"")
      echo "Installing qutebrowser..."
      sudo pacman -S --noconfirm qutebrowser
      ;;
    "\"     Brave       \"")
      echo "Installing Brave..."
      paru -S --noconfirm brave-bin
      ;;
    *)
      echo "Invalid choice: $choice"
      ;;
    esac
  done
}

# Call the browser installation function
install_browser

dialog --msgbox "Selected browsers have been installed." 10 50

clear

#!/bin/bash

echo "Setting up pacman.conf..."

# Define the lines to append
lines_to_append="ILoveCandy\nParallelDownloads=10\nColor"

# Check if the [options] section exists
if grep -q '^\[options\]' /etc/pacman.conf; then
  # Check if the lines already exist to avoid duplicates
  for line in $lines_to_append; do
    if ! grep -q "$line" /etc/pacman.conf; then
      echo -e "$line" | sudo tee -a /etc/pacman.conf > /dev/null
      echo "Added: $line"
    else
      echo "Already present: $line"
    fi
  done
else
  echo "[options] section not found. Skipping..."
fi

!/bin/bash

echo "Setting up pacman.conf..."

# Define the lines to append
lines_to_append="ILoveCandy\nParallelDownloads=10\nColor"

# Check if the [options] section exists
if grep -q '^\[options\]' /etc/pacman.conf; then
  # Append lines to the [options] section
  echo -e "$lines_to_append" | sudo tee -a /etc/pacman.conf > /dev/null
  echo "Configuration added successfully."
else
  echo "[options] section not found. Skipping..."
fi

[options]
# The following paths are commented out with their default values listed.
# If you wish to use different paths, uncomment and update the paths.
#RootDir     = /
#DBPath      = /var/lib/pacman/
#CacheDir    = /var/cache/pacman/pkg/
#LogFile     = /var/log/pacman.log
#GPGDir      = /etc/pacman.d/gnupg/
#HookDir     = /etc/pacman.d/hooks/
HoldPkg     = pacman glibc
#XferCommand = /usr/bin/curl -L -C - -f -o %o %u
#XferCommand = /usr/bin/wget --passive-ftp -c -O %o %u
#CleanMethod = KeepInstalled
Architecture = auto

# Pacman won't upgrade packages listed in IgnorePkg and members of IgnoreGroup
#IgnorePkg   =
#IgnoreGroup =

#NoUpgrade   =
#NoExtract   =

# Misc options
#UseSyslog
Color
ILoveCandy
#NoProgressBar
CheckSpace
#VerbosePkgLists
ParallelDownloads = 10
DownloadUser = alpm
#DisableSandbox

#!/bin/env bash
set -e

# Introduction & Warning
echo "Welcome to my Arch Setup!" && sleep 2
echo "Some parts of the script require sudo, so if you're planning on leaving the desktop while the installation script does its thing, better drop it already!." && sleep 4

# Creating all required home directories if not present
mkdir ~/Downloads ~/Documents ~/Music ~/Pictures ~/Videos ~/Templates

# Setting up pacman.conf
# lines_to_append="ILoveCandy\nParallelDownloads=10\nColor"
# sudo sed -i '/^\[options\]/a '"$lines_to_append" /etc/pacman.conf

# System update
echo "Performing a full system update..."
sudo pacman --noconfirm -Syu
clear
echo "System update done" && sleep 2
clear

# Install Git if not present
echo "Installing git..." && sleep 1
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm --needed git
clear

# Clone and install Paru if not installed
echo "This script requires an AUR helper to install the dependencies. Installing paru..." &
sleep 2
if ! command -v paru &>/dev/null; then
  echo "Installing Paru, an AUR helper..."
  cd Downloads
  git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/paru.git
  cd paru
  makepkg -si
  cd ..
  echo "Paru installed"
  rm -rf paru
  cd ~/dotfiles
fi
clear

echo "Setting up Git configuration..."

# Ask user whether to proceed with Git setup
if ! whiptail --title "Git Configuration Setup" --yesno "Do you want to proceed with setting up Git configuration?" 10 60; then
  echo "Git setup canceled. Exiting."
  exit 1
fi

# Prompt for Git username using whiptail
git_username=$(whiptail --inputbox "Enter your Git username:" 10 60 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)
exit_status=$?
if [ $exit_status -ne 0 ] || [ -z "$git_username" ]; then
  whiptail --msgbox "Git username setup canceled or empty. Exiting." 10 50
  exit 1
fi

# Prompt for Git email using whiptail
git_email=$(whiptail --inputbox "Enter your Git email:" 10 60 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)
exit_status=$?
if [ $exit_status -ne 0 ] || [ -z "$git_email" ]; then
  whiptail --msgbox "Git email setup canceled or empty. Exiting." 10 50
  exit 1
fi

# Display confirmation dialog
if whiptail --yesno "Please confirm the Git configuration:\n\nUsername: $git_username\nEmail: $git_email" 12 60; then
  # Set Git configuration if confirmed
  git config --global user.name "$git_username"
  git config --global user.email "$git_email"
  whiptail --msgbox "Git has been successfully configured:\n\nUsername: $git_username\nEmail: $git_email" 12 60
else

exit_status=$?
if [ $exit_status -ne 0 ]; then
  dialog --msgbox "Hyprland installation skipped. Proceeding with the setup." 10 50
  exit 0
else
  dialog --msgbox "Hyprland installation will begin now." 10 50
fi

# Install Hyprland from the official repositories or AUR
echo "Installing Hyprland..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm hyprland

# Install dependencies and useful tools for Hyprland
echo "Installing necessary dependencies for Hyprland..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm swaybg swaylock-effects waybar wayland-utils wofi rofi

# Install a default font for Wayland (like FiraCode)
echo "Installing font for Wayland..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm ttf-fira-code

# Install a basic terminal emulator (Alacritty) for Hyprland
echo "Installing terminal emulator (Alacritty)..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm alacritty

# Install a basic text editor (like Neovim)
echo "Installing text editor (Neovim)..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm neovim

# Install tools for compositor management
echo "Installing compositor utilities..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm hyprpaper

# Install a file manager (e.g., thunar) for ease of file management
echo "Installing file manager (Thunar)..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm thunar

# Install a simple web browser (e.g., Firefox)
echo "Installing web browser (Firefox)..."
sudo pacman -S --noconfirm firefox

# Set up Hyprland configuration
echo "Configuring Hyprland..."

# Create the configuration file if it doesn't exist
if [ ! -f "$HOME/.config/hypr/hyprland.conf" ]; then
  mkdir -p "$HOME/.config/hypr"
  cp /etc/xdg/hyprland/hyprland.conf "$HOME/.config/hypr/hyprland.conf"
  dialog --msgbox "Hyprland configuration file copied to $HOME/.config/hypr/hyprland.conf" 10 50
else

fi

# Inform the user that installation is complete

echo "Setting up torrent and remote working applications..."

    --checklist "Choose the applications you want to install:"  20 60 8 \
    "torrent-cli" "" OFF \
    "qBittorrent" "" OFF \
    "Transmission" "" OFF \
    "Remmina" "" OFF \
    "VNC" "" OFF \
    "TeamViewer" "" OFF \
    "AnyDesk" "" OFF \
    "xrdp" "" OFF \
    "openvpn" "" OFF \
    3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)

exit_status=$?
if [ $exit_status -ne 0 /] || [ -z "$apps" ]; then
    whiptail --msgbox "No applications selected or setup canceled. Exiting." 10 50
    exit 1
fi

for app in $apps; do

            ;;

            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm qbittorrent
            ;;
        "Transmission")
            echo "Installing Transmission..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm transmission-qt
            ;;
        "Remmina")
            echo "Installing Remmina (Remote Desktop Client)..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm remmina
            ;;

            echo "Installing VNC Server..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm tigervnc
            ;;

            echo "Installing TeamViewer..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm teamviewer

            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm anydesk
            ;;
        "xrdp")
            echo "Installing xrdp (Remote Desktop Protocol)..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm xrdp
            ;;
        "openvpn")
            echo "Installing OpenVPN..."
            sudo pacman -S --noconfirm openvpn
            ;;

            echo "Invalid choice: $app"
            ;;
    esac
done

#!/bin/bash

# Function to install packages
install_package() {
    if pacman -Qs "$1" > /dev/null ; then
        whiptail --msgbox "$1 is already installed." 8 78
    else
        whiptail --msgbox "Installing $1..." 8 78
        sudo pacman -S --noconfirm "$1"
    fi
}

# Whiptail dialog
whiptail --title "Package Installer" --msgbox "Welcome to the package installation script!" 8 78

# List of packages to install
packages=(
    "vscode"
    "github-desktop"
    "docker"
    "docker-desktop"
    "kubernetes"
    "libreoffice-fresh"  # Office package
    "discord"
    "texlive-most"  # LaTeX package
    "miniconda"
)

# Install packages
for package in "${packages[@]}"; do
    install_package "$package"
done

#!/bin/bash

echo "Installing main packages and applications that I personally use the most..."
sleep 1

# Function to display the browser selection menu
install_browser() {
    # Display the checkbox menu
    choices=$(whiptail --title "Browser Selection" \
        --checklist "Select the browsers you want to install:" 15 50 6 \
        "   Zen-Browser   " "" OFF \
        "     Firefox     " "" OFF \
        "    Chromium     " "" OFF \
        "     Vivaldi     " "" OFF \
        "   qutebrowser   " "" OFF \
        "     Brave       " "" OFF \
        3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)
    
    # Check if the user pressed Cancel
    if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
        echo "No selection made. Exiting."
        exit 1
    fi

    # Process the selected options
    for choice in $choices; do
        case $choice in
            "\"   Zen-Browser   \"")
                echo "Installing Zen-Browser..."
                # Replace with Zen-Browser installation commands
                ;;
            "\"     Firefox     \"")
                echo "Installing Firefox..."
                sudo apt-get install -y firefox
                ;;
            "\"    Chromium     \"")
                echo "Installing Chromium..."
                sudo apt-get install -y chromium-browser
                ;;
            "\"     Vivaldi     \"")
                echo "Installing Vivaldi..."
                wget -qO- https://repo.vivaldi.com/archive/linux_signing_key.pub | sudo apt-key add -
                echo "deb [arch=amd64] https://repo.vivaldi.com/archive/deb/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/vivaldi.list
                sudo apt update
                sudo apt install -y vivaldi-stable
                ;;
            "\"   qutebrowser   \"")
                echo "Installing qutebrowser..."
                sudo apt-get install -y qutebrowser
                ;;
            "\"     Brave       \"")
                echo "Installing Brave..."
                sudo apt install -y apt-transport-https curl
                curl -fsSL https://brave-browser-apt-release.s3.brave.com/brave-core.asc | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/brave-browser-archive-keyring.gpg
                echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/brave-browser-archive-keyring.gpg] https://brave-browser-apt-release.s3.brave.com/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/brave-browser-release.list
                sudo apt update
                sudo apt install -y brave-browser
                ;;
            *)
                echo "Invalid choice: $choice"
                ;;
        esac
    done
}

# Call the browser installation function
install_browser

#!/bin/bash

echo "Installing main packages and applications that I personally use the most..."
sleep 2

# Function to display the browser selection menu
install_browser() {
    # Display the checkbox menu
    choices=$(whiptail --title "Browser Selection" \
        --checklist "Select the browsers you want to install:" 15 50 6 \
        "   Zen-Browser   " "" OFF \
        "     Firefox     " "" OFF \
        "    Chromium     " "" OFF \
        "     Vivaldi     " "" OFF \
        "   qutebrowser   " "" OFF \
        "     Brave       " "" OFF \
        3>&1 1>&2 2>&3)
    
    # Check if the user pressed Cancel
    if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
        echo "No selection made. Exiting."
        exit 1
    fi

    # Process the selected options
    for choice in $choices; do
        case $choice in
            "\"   Zen-Browser   \"")
                echo "Installing Zen-Browser..."
                # Replace with Zen-Browser installation commands
                ;;
            "\"     Firefox     \"")
                echo "Installing Firefox..."
                sudo apt-get install -y firefox
                ;;
            "\"    Chromium     \"")
                echo "Installing Chromium..."
                sudo apt-get install -y chromium-browser
                ;;
            "\"     Vivaldi     \"")
                echo "Installing Vivaldi..."
                wget -qO- https://repo.vivaldi.com/archive/linux_signing_key.pub | sudo apt-key add -
                echo "deb [arch=amd64] https://repo.vivaldi.com/archive/deb/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/vivaldi.list
                sudo apt update
                sudo apt install -y vivaldi-stable
                ;;
            "\"   qutebrowser   \"")
                echo "Installing qutebrowser..."
                sudo apt-get install -y qutebrowser
                ;;
            "\"     Brave       \"")
                echo "Installing Brave..."
                sudo apt install -y apt-transport-https curl
                curl -fsSL https://brave-browser-apt-release.s3.brave.com/brave-core.asc | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/brave-browser-archive-keyring.gpg
                echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/brave-browser-archive-keyring.gpg] https://brave-browser-apt-release.s3.brave.com/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/brave-browser-release.list
                sudo apt update
                sudo apt install -y brave-browser
                ;;
            *)
                echo "Invalid choice: $choice"
                ;;
        esac
    done
}

# Call the browser installation function
install_browser

#  Kubernetes API Server: The Cluster's Gateway

The **API Server** is the heart of Kubernetes, acting as the primary interface for all cluster operations. It processes requests from users, internal components, and external systems, ensuring the cluster operates smoothly and securely.

---

##  Key Roles and Responsibilities

1. **Central Communication Hub**:  
   - Serves as the single point of interaction for cluster management.  
   - Handles requests from `kubectl`, dashboards, and automated systems.  

2. **Authentication and Authorization**:  
   - Verifies who you are (**authentication**) and what you're allowed to do (**authorization**).  

3. **Validation**:  
   - Ensures incoming requests are correctly structured and logical.  

4. **Persistence**:  
   - Stores and retrieves the clusters state in **etcd**, maintaining a single source of truth.  

5. **Cluster State Management**:  
   - Manages the desired and current states of the cluster resources.  

6. **Real-Time Monitoring**:  
   - Supports "watch" requests, enabling clients to track resource changes in real time.  

7. **Load Balancing and High Availability**:  
   - Distributes requests across multiple API Servers in high-availability setups.  

---

##  API Server Workflow

1. **Receive Request**:  
   - Processes requests from `kubectl`, external apps, or other components.  

2. **Authentication**:  
   - Validates the requester using tokens, certificates, or plugins.  

3. **Authorization**:  
   - Checks permissions via RBAC or other authorization mechanisms.  

4. **Admission Control**:  
   - Applies policies like resource quotas and security constraints.  

5. **Validation**:  
   - Ensures requests conform to the API schema.  

6. **Persistence and Update**:  
   - Updates **etcd** for any state changes and notifies relevant components.  

7. **Response**:  
   - Returns the result (e.g., resource details or operation status).  

---

##  Features of the API Server

1. **RESTful Interface**:  
   - Offers a RESTful API for seamless programmatic interaction.  

2. **Extensibility**:  
   - Supports **Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs)** to extend Kubernetes functionality.  

3. **Scalability**:  
   - Handles high request volumes efficiently in large clusters.  

4. **Self-Healing**:  
   - Works with controllers and the scheduler to maintain cluster health.  

---

##  Example Scenarios

1. **Pod Deployment**:  
   - A `kubectl apply` command sends a request to the API Server, which validates and stores the Pod's configuration in **etcd**.  

2. **Cluster Monitoring**:  
   - A monitoring system uses the "watch" feature to get real-time updates on resource changes.  

3. **Security Enforcement**:  
   - The API Server ensures only authorized users can modify critical resources.  

---

##  Best Practices

- **Monitor Traffic**: Use tools like `kube-apiserver` metrics to analyze request patterns.  
- **Secure Communications**: Enforce TLS and authenticate using secure tokens or certificates.  
- **Optimize RBAC**: Regularly review and refine Role-Based Access Controls.  
- **Scale API Servers**: Add replicas in high-traffic environments for improved performance.

- **API SERVER** : This is the main part of the Kubernetes which takes the requests and send the data or requests from users. Using this server, clients interact with the cluster.
	
	- ### Key Roles and Responsibilities of the API Server:

		1. **Central Communication Hub**:
		    
		    - The API Server acts as the single point of interaction for all cluster operations. It receives requests from users (e.g., `kubectl` commands), internal cluster components, and external applications.
		2. **Authentication and Authorization**:
		    
		    - Ensures that users or components making API requests are authenticated (who you are) and authorized (what you can do).
		3. **Validation**:
		    
		    - Validates API requests to ensure they conform to the required schema and logic before processing them.
		4. **Persistence**:
		    
		    - Interacts with **etcd** (the cluster's key-value store) to store and retrieve the state of the cluster. Any updates made via the API Server are persisted in `etcd`.
		5. **Cluster State Management**:
		    
		    - Serves as the source of truth for the current state of the cluster and manages desired state declarations.
		6. **Handling Watch Requests**:
		    
		    - Supports the "watch" mechanism for monitoring changes in resources. Clients can watch for updates (e.g., new Pods, changes to ConfigMaps) in real time.
		7. **Load Balancing and High Availability**:
		    
		    - In a multi-master setup, API Servers are load-balanced to ensure high availability and fault tolerance.
		
		### API Server Workflow:
	
		1. **Receive Request**:
			
			- A request arrives at the API Server (e.g., via `kubectl`, a dashboard, or an automated system).
		2. **Authentication**:
			
			- The server verifies the identity of the requester using mechanisms like tokens, certificates, or authentication plugins.
		3. **Authorization**:
			
			- Checks if the requester has permission to perform the requested action using Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) or other mechanisms.
		4. **Admission Control**:
			
			- Admission controllers validate and modify requests according to policies (e.g., resource quotas, security policies).
		5. **Validation**:
			
			- The request is checked against the API's schema to ensure its correctly structured.
		6. **Persistence and Update**:
			
			- If the request modifies the cluster, the API Server updates the state in **etcd** and notifies relevant components.
		7. **Response**:
			
			- Returns the result of the request (e.g., resource details, status of operation).
	
		### Features:
	
		1. **RESTful Interface**:
			
			- The Kubernetes API Server provides a RESTful interface, making it easy to interact programmatically.
		2. **Extensibility**:
			
			- Supports custom resources (Custom Resource Definitions - CRDs), enabling you to extend Kubernetes with your own APIs.
		3. **Scalability**:
			
			- Designed to handle a large number of API requests efficiently in large-scale clusters.
		4. **Self-Healing**:
			
			- Works with the controller-manager and scheduler to reconcile the cluster's current state with its desired state.

#  Kubernetes Scheduler: The Cluster Matchmaker

The **scheduler** is a vital part of Kubernetes' control plane, responsible for assigning Pods to the most suitable worker nodes. It ensures optimal resource utilization and enforces scheduling policies to maintain a balanced and efficient cluster.

---

##  Key Functions of the Scheduler

1. **Node Selection**:  
   - Chooses the best node for a Pod based on resource availability, constraints, and affinity rules.  

2. **Resource Awareness**:  
   - Ensures nodes have enough CPU, memory, and other resources to run the Pod.  

3. **Policy Enforcement**:  
   - Implements policies like:  
     - **Node Affinity/Anti-Affinity**: Determines co-location or separation of Pods.  
     - **Taints and Tolerations**: Matches Pods with compatible nodes.  
     - **Pod Affinity/Anti-Affinity**: Governs scheduling relative to other Pods.  

4. **Priority and Preemption**:  
   - Honors Pod priorities and may preempt lower-priority Pods for higher-priority workloads.  

5. **Topology Awareness**:  
   - Considers zones and regions to ensure fault tolerance and reduce latency.  

---

##  Workflow of the Scheduler

1. **Input**:  
   - Identifies Pods that need scheduling (no assigned node).  

2. **Filtering**:  
   - Eliminates unsuitable nodes based on:  
     - Node conditions (e.g., memory pressure, disk issues).  
     - Resource requests vs. available capacity.  
     - Policies like taints, tolerations, and affinity rules.  

3. **Scoring**:  
   - Scores remaining nodes by evaluating factors like:  
     - Resource balance.  
     - Pod affinity and anti-affinity preferences.  

4. **Binding**:  
   - Assigns the Pod to the highest-scoring node and updates the API Server.  

---

##  Extensibility

The Kubernetes Scheduler is highly customizable:  

1. **Custom Schedulers**:  
   - Create a scheduler tailored to specific needs.  

2. **Scheduling Framework**:  
   - Use plugins for custom filtering, scoring, or additional scheduling logic.  

---

##  Example Scenarios

1. **Resource Constraints**:  
   - A Pod requesting 4 CPUs and 8GB memory is scheduled to a node with adequate resources.  

2. **Affinity Rules**:  
   - A Pod with **Node Affinity** is placed on a preferred node (e.g., in a specific zone).  

3. **Priority Handling**:  
   - A high-priority Pod preempts a low-priority Pod when resources are scarce.  

---

##  Best Practices

- Monitor scheduler performance and logs for bottlenecks or errors.  
- Use **taints** and **tolerations** to optimize resource usage.  
- Implement **custom plugins** for unique scheduling requirements.  
- Regularly review **Pod priorities** to ensure critical workloads are prioritized.

#  etcd: The Backbone of Kubernetes

**etcd** is Kubernetes' **key-value store** and the **source of truth** for cluster data. It's distributed, highly available, and ensures data consistency.  

---

##  What Makes etcd Special?

1. **Strong Consistency**:  
   Uses the **Raft consensus algorithm** for consistent data across nodes.  

2. **High Availability**:  
   Distributed design ensures no single point of failure.  

3. **Durable**:  
   Data is persisted to disk, surviving restarts or failures.  

4. **Low Latency**:  
   Optimized for real-time cluster state updates.  

5. **Scalable**:  
   Handles high request volumes, perfect for large clusters.  

---

##  Role of etcd in Kubernetes

1. **Cluster State Storage**:  
   Stores everything: Nodes, Pods, ConfigMaps, Secrets, CRDs, etc.  

2. **Leader Election**:  
   Helps control plane components elect a leader (e.g., Scheduler).  

3. **Watch Mechanism**:  
   Enables components to react instantly to state changes.  

4. **Backup & Restore**:  
   Critical for disaster recovery.

---

##  How etcd Works

1. **Key-Value Store**:  
   Stores data like:  
   - Key: `/registry/pods/default/my-pod`  
   - Value: Pod's JSON/YAML configuration.  

2. **API Server Interaction**:  
   - API Server writes state to etcd.  
   - Other components read from it and act.  

3. **Replication & Consensus**:  
   - Data is replicated across nodes.  
   - Writes go to the leader; followers stay in sync.

---

##  Deployment Tips

1. **HA Setup**:  
   - Use 3 or 5 nodes for quorum-based fault tolerance.  

2. **Secure Communication**:  
   - Encrypt traffic with TLS.  

3. **Fast Storage**:  
   - Use SSDs for performance.  

4. **Regular Backups**:  
   - Tools: `etcdctl`, Kubernetes backup mechanisms.  

---

##  Best Practices

- Monitor health: Disk latency, memory, and leader elections.  
- Regular updates to avoid vulnerabilities.  
- Secure access with strong authentication.  

---

#  Kubernetes Controller Manager

The **Controller Manager** ensures Kubernetes runs like a well-oiled machine! It coordinates controllers to maintain the cluster's **desired state**.  

---

##  Key Roles

1. **State Reconciliation**:  
   Keeps the actual state aligned with the desired state (e.g., reschedules crashed Pods).  

2. **Controller Aggregation**:  
   Combines multiple controllers into a single process for simplicity.  

3. **Resource Management**:  
   Automates tasks like scaling, scheduling, and repairs.  

---

##  Controllers Overview

1. **Node Controller**:  
   Handles node health and reschedules Pods from failed nodes.  

2. **Replication Controller**:  
   Ensures the desired number of Pod replicas are running.  

3. **Deployment Controller**:  
   Manages rollouts, updates, and rollbacks of Deployments.  

4. **DaemonSet Controller**:  
   Ensures a Pod copy runs on all/specific nodes.  

5. **Job Controller**:  
   Ensures Pods complete tasks for Jobs.  

6. **Endpoint Controller**:  
   Updates IP addresses for Services.  

7. **Service Account Controller**:  
   Manages default ServiceAccounts and their secrets.  

8. **Resource Quota Controller**:  
   Enforces resource usage limits in namespaces.  

9. **PV Controller**:  
   Manages Persistent Volumes and bindings to PVCs.  

---

##  Workflow of the Controller Manager

1. **Watch**:  
   Monitors desired state via API Server.  

2. **Reconcile**:  
   Fixes mismatches (e.g., recreates deleted Pods).  

3. **Update State**:  
   Updates the cluster state and persists changes in etcd.  

---

##  Features

- **Leader Election**: Ensures only one active instance in HA setups.  
- **Modularity**: Independent controllers simplify debugging.  
- **Extendability**: Add custom controllers for specialized tasks.  

---

##  Example Scenarios

1. **Node Failure**:  
   Node Controller detects a failure, marks it "NotReady," and reschedules Pods.  

2. **Replica Management**:  
   If a Pod in a Deployment crashes, the Replication Controller creates a new one.  

3. **Resource Binding**:  
   The PV Controller binds a PVC to an available PV.  

---

##  Best Practices

- **Monitor Logs**: Ensure controllers are functioning properly.  
- **Enable Leader Election**: Avoid conflicts in HA setups.  
- **Develop Custom Controllers**: Extend Kubernetes for unique workflows.

- **ETCD** : **etcd** is a distributed, highly available, and consistent key-value store that serves as the **backbone** of Kubernetes' control plane. It stores the entire state and configuration of the Kubernetes cluster, making it a critical component for cluster operation and reliability.

	**LAYMAN ** : Generally it is a database to store the values, but its specialty is to store in JSON(key: value) format which helps to make custom keys for custom values unlike in the RDBMS we have to specify a key for every value. 

	### **Key Features of etcd:**

	1. **Strong Consistency**:
		
		- etcd uses the **Raft consensus algorithm** to ensure that data is strongly consistent across all nodes in the etcd cluster.
	2. **High Availability**:
		
		- By running as a distributed system, etcd ensures high availability through leader election and replication. If one node fails, other nodes in the etcd cluster continue to operate.
	3. **Durability**:
		
		- All data in etcd is persisted to disk, ensuring durability even in the event of node restarts or failures.
	4. **Low Latency**:
		
		- Optimized for fast reads and writes, making it suitable for managing cluster state in real time.
	5. **Scalability**:
		
		- Can handle high volumes of requests, making it ideal for large-scale clusters.

	### **Role of etcd in Kubernetes:**

	1. **Cluster State Storage**:
		
		- etcd acts as the **source of truth** for the Kubernetes cluster, storing all cluster data, including:
			- Node and Pod information
			- Configurations (e.g., ConfigMaps, Secrets)
			- Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs)
			- Networking information (e.g., Services, Endpoints)
			- Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs)
	2. **Leader Election**:
		
		- Used for leader election among control plane components like the Kubernetes Controller Manager and Scheduler.
	3. **Watch Mechanism**:
		
		- etcd supports a **watch** feature, enabling Kubernetes components to subscribe to changes in cluster state and react in real time.
	4. **Backup and Restore**:
		
		- Since it stores the clusters state, regular backups of etcd are crucial for disaster recovery.

	### **How etcd Works in Kubernetes:**

	1. **Data Storage**:
		
		- All objects and configurations are stored as key-value pairs. For example:
			- Key: `/registry/pods/default/my-pod`
			- Value: Detailed JSON/YAML representation of the Pod's configuration.
	2. **Interaction with API Server**:
		
		- The API Server interacts with etcd to retrieve or persist cluster state.
		- For example:
			- When a new Pod is created, the API Server writes the Pod's desired state to etcd.
			- Other control plane components read this state and act accordingly (e.g., the scheduler assigns the Pod to a node).
	3. **Replication and Consensus**:
		
		- etcd replicates data across all its nodes and uses the Raft consensus algorithm to ensure consistency. Only one node acts as the leader, and write requests are sent to the leader.

	### **Deployment in Kubernetes:**

	- **Embedded in the Control Plane**:
		
		- etcd is typically deployed alongside other control plane components in a highly available configuration.
		- A typical Kubernetes HA setup includes multiple etcd instances (e.g., 3 or 5) for fault tolerance.
	- **Secured Communication**:
		
		- Communication between etcd and other components (like the API Server) is secured using Transport Layer Security (TLS).

	### **Best Practices for etcd:**

	1. **Regular Backups**:
		
		- Use tools like `etcdctl` or Kubernetes' built-in backup mechanisms to regularly back up etcd data.
	2. **Cluster Size**:
		
		- Deploy an odd number of etcd nodes (e.g., 3, 5) to ensure quorum-based consensus.
	3. **Monitor Health**:
		
		- Monitor metrics like disk latency, memory usage, and leader election frequency to ensure etcd is healthy.
	4. **Use Fast Storage**:
		
		- Store etcd data on high-performance SSDs to minimize latency and ensure reliable performance.
	5. **Secure Configuration**:
		
		- Use strong authentication and encryption (TLS) to secure etcd communications and data.

- **CONTROLLER MANAGER**: The **Controller Manager** is a core component of the Kubernetes control plane responsible for managing various controllers that regulate the state of the cluster. Each controller is a loop that monitors the cluster's desired state (as defined in etcd via the API Server) and works to reconcile it with the actual state.

	### Key Roles of the Kubernetes Controller Manager:
	
	1. **State Reconciliation**:
	    
	    - Ensures the actual state of the cluster matches the desired state defined by users and stored in etcd. For example, if a Pod crashes, a controller ensures it's rescheduled.
	2. **Controller Coordination**:
	    
	    - The Controller Manager aggregates several individual controllers into a single binary, simplifying operations and resource management.
	3. **Resource Management**:
	    
	    - Manages resources like nodes, Pods, ReplicationControllers, and more by automating operations such as scaling, scheduling, and repairing.
	
	### **Types of Controllers in the Controller Manager:**
	
	1. **Node Controller**:
	    
	    - Monitors the health of nodes.
	    - Detects node failures and triggers actions like marking the node as "NotReady" and rescheduling Pods elsewhere.
	2. **Replication Controller**:
	    
	    - Ensures that the desired number of Pod replicas for a ReplicationController or ReplicaSet exists at any given time.
	3. **Deployment Controller**:
	    
	    - Manages the rollout and scaling of Deployments.
	    - Handles rolling updates and rollbacks.
	4. **DaemonSet Controller**:
	    
	    - Ensures that a copy of a specific Pod runs on all (or a subset of) nodes.
	5. **Job Controller**:
	    
	    - Manages Job objects, ensuring Pods complete their tasks successfully.
	6. **Endpoint Controller**:
	    
	    - Populates the Endpoints object with the IP addresses of Pods associated with a Service.
	7. **Service Account Controller**:
	    
	    - Creates default ServiceAccounts for namespaces and manages their secrets.
	8. **Resource Quota Controller**:
	    
	    - Ensures that resource usage within a namespace does not exceed predefined quotas.
	9. **Persistent Volume (PV) Controller**:
	    
	    - Manages the lifecycle of Persistent Volumes and their binding to Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs).
	
	### Workflow of the Controller Manager:
	
	1. **Watch the Cluster State**:
	    
	    - The Controller Manager communicates with the API Server to "watch" for changes in the cluster's desired state.
	2. **Reconcile State**:
	    
	    - If theres a mismatch between the desired state and the actual state (e.g., a Pod is deleted or a node becomes unhealthy), the corresponding controller takes action.
	3. **Update Cluster State**:
	    
	    - The controller performs the necessary operations (e.g., creating a new Pod, unbinding a PVC) and updates the API Server, which then persists changes to etcd.
	
	### Deployment:
	
	- The Kubernetes Controller Manager runs as a single process but includes multiple controllers.
	- In High Availability (HA) setups, it runs on multiple master nodes, but **leader election** ensures only one instance is active at a time.
	
	### Features:
	
	1. **Leader Election**:
	    
	    - Ensures high availability by electing a single active Controller Manager in an HA setup.
	2. **Extendability**:
	    
	    - Kubernetes allows custom controllers to extend cluster functionality (e.g., for managing custom resources or workflows).
	3. **Modular Design**:
	    
	    - Individual controllers work independently, making the system modular and easier to debug or extend.
	
	### Example Scenarios:
	
	1. **Node Failure**:
	    
	    - The Node Controller detects that a node is down.
	    - It marks the node as "NotReady" and ensures all Pods on that node are rescheduled on healthy nodes.
	2. **Replica Management**:
	    
	    - A Deployment specifies that 5 replicas of a Pod should run.
	    - If one Pod crashes, the Replication Controller ensures a new Pod is created to maintain 5 replicas.
	3. **Resource Binding**:
	    
	    - A user creates a Persistent Volume Claim (PVC).
	    - The Persistent Volume Controller binds the PVC to an available Persistent Volume (PV).
	
	### Best Practices:
	
	1. **Monitoring**:
	    
	    - Monitor logs and metrics from the Controller Manager to ensure controllers are reconciling state effectively.
	2. **Leader Election**:
	    
	    - Use leader election to avoid conflicts in HA setups.
	3. **Custom Controllers**:
	    
	    - For specialized workflows, develop custom controllers using Kubernetes' controller-runtime library.

#  Worker Node in Kubernetes

A **Worker Node** is where your **apps live and thrive** in Kubernetes! It's the powerhouse that runs Pods, hosts containers, and manages resources. Let's break it down!  

---

##  Key Components

1. **Kubelet**:  
   - The worker node's **brain**!  
   - Talks to the API server, ensures Pods are running, and reports node status.  

2. **Container Runtime**:  
   - The **engine** that runs your containers.  
   - Examples: `Docker`, `containerd`, `CRI-O`.

3. **Kube-Proxy**:  
   - The **networking wizard**!  
   - Routes traffic to/from Pods and handles load balancing.  

4. **Operating System**:  
   - The base for all Kubernetes magic!  
   - Popular choices: Ubuntu, CentOS, CoreOS.

---

##  Responsibilities

1. **Host Pods**: Runs app workloads.  
2. **Networking**: Enables inter-Pod and external communication.  
3. **Monitor Health**: Reports resource usage & status.  
4. **Scale & Load Balance**: Shares workloads with other nodes.

---

##  Workflow in Action

1. **Pod Scheduling**: Scheduler assigns Pods  Kubelet sets them up.  
2. **Run Containers**: Container runtime pulls images and launches containers.  
3. **Allocate Resources**: Pods get CPU, memory, etc., as per their needs.  
4. **Networking**: Kube-proxy ensures smooth traffic flow.  
5. **Health Check**: Kubelet monitors containers and restarts them if needed.

---

##  Features

- **Scalable**: Add more nodes to handle more workloads.  
- **Fault-Tolerant**: Failing nodes? Pods are rescheduled elsewhere.  
- **Resource Isolation**: Keeps Pods secure using namespaces and cgroups.  
- **Smart Resource Management**: Efficient and stable resource usage.  

---

##  Deployment & Maintenance Tips

- **Node Labels & Taints**: Organize workloads intelligently (e.g., GPU nodes).  
- **Monitoring**: Use tools like Prometheus/Grafana for insights.  
- **Upgrades**: Keep OS and Kubernetes updated for security and stability.  
- **Autoscaling**: Ensure high availability with auto-scaling and health checks.  

---

##  Best Practices

1. **Allocate Sufficient Resources**: Avoid bottlenecks.  
2. **Stay Updated**: Patch vulnerabilities and improve performance.  
3. **Use Quotas**: Prevent Pods from hogging resources.  
4. **Label Nodes**: Optimize workload distribution.  

---

Kubernetes Worker Nodes: **Simple, Scalable, Powerful!**

Now this is the **MASTER NODE**, coming to **WORKER NODE**, it also contains 2 different components 
1. KUBE-PROXY
2. KUBELET

**A worker node in Kubernetes is where the actual application workloads (containers) run. It is a critical part of the Kubernetes cluster that provides the compute, memory, storage, and networking resources necessary to host and manage Pods. Each worker node communicates with the Kubernetes control plane to perform its assigned tasks.**

### Key Components of a Worker Node:

1. **Kubelet**:
    
    - The primary agent on the worker node that communicates with the Kubernetes API Server.
    - It ensures that the Pods scheduled to the node are running as expected.
    - Periodically reports the status of the node and its running Pods back to the control plane.
2. **Container Runtime**:
    
    - Responsible for running containers. Kubernetes supports multiple container runtimes, including:
        - Docker
        - containerd
        - CRI-O
    - The runtime pulls container images, starts containers, and manages their lifecycle.
3. **Kube-Proxy**:
    
    - A network proxy that manages networking rules on the node.
    - It ensures that network traffic is correctly routed to and from Pods running on the node.
    - Supports Services by load-balancing traffic between Pods.
4. **Operating System**:
    
    - The base layer that hosts the Kubernetes components and container runtime. Common OS choices include Linux distributions like Ubuntu, CentOS, or specialized Kubernetes OSes like CoreOS.

### Responsibilities of a Worker Node:

1. **Hosting Pods**:
    
    - Worker nodes run the application Pods as scheduled by the Kubernetes Scheduler.
2. **Networking**:
    
    - Ensures inter-Pod communication and manages traffic between external clients and the cluster.
3. **Monitoring and Reporting**:
    
    - Continuously reports its health and resource usage (e.g., CPU, memory, disk) to the control plane.
4. **Scaling and Load Distribution**:
    
    - Shares the cluster's workload with other worker nodes, allowing Kubernetes to scale applications across the nodes.

### Workflow of a Worker Node:

1. **Pod Scheduling**:
    
    - The Kubernetes Scheduler assigns Pods to the worker node.
    - The kubelet on the node receives instructions to create the Pods.
2. **Container Runtime**:
    
    - The container runtime pulls the required container images from a container registry and starts the containers.
3. **Resource Allocation**:
    
    - The node's resources (CPU, memory, disk) are allocated to running containers as per the Pod specifications.
4. **Networking**:
    
    - The kube-proxy configures networking rules to route traffic to and from Pods.
    - Pods can communicate with other Pods on the same or different nodes.
5. **Monitoring**:
    
    - The kubelet monitors the health of the containers and ensures they remain in the desired state. If a container fails, kubelet attempts to restart it.

### Features of a Worker Node:

1. **Scalability**:
    
    - New worker nodes can be added to the cluster to handle increased workloads.
2. **Fault Tolerance**:
    
    - If a worker node fails, the control plane reschedules the affected Pods on other available nodes.
3. **Resource Isolation**:
    
    - Ensures that Pods running on the same node are isolated from one another using container runtime features like namespaces and cgroups.
4. **Flexible Resource Management**:
    
    - Nodes support overcommitting resources, allowing efficient utilization while maintaining stability.

### Deployment and Configuration:

1. **Node Registration**:
    
    - Each worker node registers itself with the control plane using the kubelet.
2. **Labels and Taints**:
    
    - Nodes can have labels to specify their capabilities (e.g., `region=us-east`).
    - Taints can prevent certain workloads from being scheduled on specific nodes unless the workloads tolerate those taints.
3. **Node Pooling**:
    
    - In managed Kubernetes services (e.g., GKE, EKS, AKS), worker nodes are often organized into "node pools" for easier management.

### Monitoring and Maintenance:

1. **Monitoring Tools**:
    
    - Tools like Prometheus, Grafana, or Kubernetes Dashboard can be used to monitor node health and performance.
2. **Resource Usage**:
    
    - Continuously monitor CPU, memory, and disk usage to prevent resource exhaustion.
3. **Upgrades**:
    
    - Worker nodes should be upgraded to keep their Kubernetes components and OS up to date.
4. **Fault Recovery**:
    
    - Use node autoscaling and health checks to ensure continuous availability in case of node failures.

### Best Practices:

1. **Ensure Sufficient Resources**:
    
    - Allocate adequate CPU, memory, and storage to handle expected workloads.
2. **Regular Updates**:
    
    - Keep the node OS and Kubernetes components updated to avoid security vulnerabilities and compatibility issues.
3. **Resource Quotas**:
    
    - Use resource quotas to prevent any Pod from monopolizing node resources.
4. **Use Node Labels**:
    
    - Label nodes to facilitate intelligent workload scheduling (e.g., running GPU-intensive workloads on GPU nodes).

Docker Login using Pass in CLI
Add credsStore to your docker config. This can be done with sed if you don't already have credStore added to your config or you can manually add "credStore":"pass" to the config.json.
Initialize pass using the newly created key

wget https://github.com/docker/docker-credential-helpers/releases/download/v0.6.0/docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && tar -xf docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && chmod +x docker-credential-pass && sudo mv docker-credential-pass /usr/local/bin/
Download, extract, make executable, and move docker-credential-pass
Generally when we are using CLI version of docker preferably in linux (I use Arch BTW  )

wget https://github.com/docker/docker-credential-helpers/releases/download/v0.6.0/docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && tar -xf docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && chmod +x docker-credential-pass && sudo mv docker-credential-pass /usr/local/bin/

Install pass

sudo apt-get install pass

    Download, extract, make executable, and move docker-credential-pass

wget https://github.com/docker/docker-credential-helpers/releases/download/v0.6.0/docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && tar -xf docker-credential-pass-v0.6.0-amd64.tar.gz && chmod +x docker-credential-pass && sudo mv docker-credential-pass /usr/local/bin/

    Create a new gpg2 key.

gpg2 --gen-key

    Follow prompts from gpg2 utility

    Initialize pass using the newly created key

pass init "<Your Name>"

    Add credsStore to your docker config. This can be done with sed if you don't already have credStore added to your config or you can manually add "credStore":"pass" to the config.json.

sed -i '0,/{/s/{/{\n\t"credsStore": "pass",/' ~/.docker/config.json

    Login to docker

docker login
